source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_042_chunk5
evidence_span: The effect of prefilming in steam on the appearance of oxides following 157-days' irradiation in high-oxygen water is shown in Fig. 8. With one exception, the darker appearance of the oxide on specimens that had been prefilmed in steam prior to irradiation, compared to those that were not, is consistent with the lower weight gains measured on these specimens and is indicative of the inhibiting effect the steam-formed oxides have on subsequent inreactor corrosion in oxygenated water.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_042_chunk5
evidence_span: For Zircaloy-2, preoxidation to about $1 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ suppressed the formation of white oxide that was seen to form on bare specimens in the same test.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_042_chunk5
evidence_span: The mottled, grey appearance of the specimen prefilmed to about $9 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ prior to irradiation is largely due to the initial prefilming treatment.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_042_chunk5
evidence_span: In the case of ${ \cal Z } \mathbf { r } { - } 2 . 5 \mathbf { N } \mathbf { b }$ , the effect of the oxygen is to increase the oxidation rate by promoting the formation of a high density of small white oxide pustules over the entire surface.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_042_chunk5
evidence_span: Preoxidation in 673 K steam inhibits the formation of these white oxide pustules.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_042_chunk5
evidence_span: The tendency to form pustules in reactor decreases with increasing thickness of the prefilmed oxide and the corresponding oxidation rate is less.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_042_chunk5
evidence_span: Figure 9 shows the average oxidation rates as a function of temperature for bare Zircaloy-2 and $\mathbf { \delta Z r { - } } 2 . 5 \mathbf { N b }$ specimens after 200-days' exposure. The inreactor oxidation rates for both alloys are reasonably similar over this time period.

evidence_span: For Zircaloy-2 the equivalent expression is $S = 1 . 8 \exp ( - 6 0 6 9 / R T )$

evidence_span: For both alloys the in-reactor corrosion rate increases by about a factor of two over a 40 K increase in temperature.

evidence_span: For both alloys the in-reactor corrosion rate increases by about a factor of two over a 40 K increase in temperature.

evidence_span: For $Z \mathrm { r } { - } 2 . 5 \mathrm { N b }$ , a suppression in corrosion during irradiation is seen similar to results from the U2 loop described earlier.
